If you can't code it yourself, no one will be able to. Spending money paying a dev and then trying to explain the algorithm in your head to them then being frustrated that they can't get it to work while still costing money will be very frustrating. You need to write a proof-of-concept version yourself and prove that it works for compressing and decompressing arbitrary data. If you are not a seasoned developer yet this has the added benefit of increasing your programming skills. In any case, once you have proof, you will be in a totally different place than now and can persue patents, raise investments or sell licences. Bear in mind that encryption is a very well-studied field, both theoretically and from an engineering perpective. The chances to just stumble on a any general enhancement to the state of art, let alone a significant one, are very low. But don't let that stop you, whatever you develop persuing this will further your understanding and make you more employable as a developer while costing only your time, so you can't lose.

Just as a thought: Effective Altruism says you should take a high-paying job and donate the money, rather than taking a low-paying job that directly does good, if you want to help the world most effectively.

The Effective Altruism argument is that if you don't take the high-paying job, someone else will, and they won't be donating the earnings. Therefore, it is always better to take the high-paying job, even if it is evil, as long as you are not the only person on earth that would take the job. I don't necessarily think this is true, I'm just presenting the argument.

Yes, false dichotomy. An example: Lets say women in Switzerland earn 6% less than men on average. Outcome Equality Person: This is wrong! We must implement measures to enable women to earn more money! Opportunity Equality Person: No, those measures would create an unfair advantage for women. That would be unequal opportunity. Outcome Equality Person: As the current salary difference indicates, women clearly already have worse opportunities, otherwise they would not earn less on average. So the measures would simply close the gap, leading to equal opportunity. Opportunity Equality Person: Well maybe opportunity is already equal, and women are just lazy. I don't think measures are needed to reward them for their laziness. Equality of Opportunity and Equality of Outcome are equal under the premise that every person is capable and willing to seize offered opportunities, on average, to the same degree. Only by rejecting that premise does this dichotomy appear. If women are lazy, then no equality in outcome can exist even if there are equal opportunities for everyone. Successful people who enjoyed greater than average opportunity often misinterpret the opportunity they were able to seize with their own work ethic. They feel that people who are not as successful wasted their opportunity. It is an easy mistake to make, as even with an advantage in opportunity hard work is required for success. In the end, opportunity is impossible to measure, only outcome can be measured. And under the premise that all humans are equal, they are the same. So it is moral to strive for equal opportunity by using equal outcome as a measure for it.

You do lose momentum as you age, but also, you become more realistic. Not everyone will be a world-champion in sports or a famous actor. Realizing you are not as special as you once thought you were is a part of growing up. If your goal is concrete and obtainable, but very far away (travel the world for a year), then you need to find a concrete step in the right direction and do it. As soon as you are working on your plan, you will feel better.

Yeah fuck that guy, but to help you out: Provide a list of tasks and their estimated time, then multiply by your price per hour to get an offer. That way, if the client wants to pay less, he will see that he needs to cut down on the number tasks in the project, he can't just demand the same for less money. Try not to be apologetic about your prices, just estimate the hours needed and price accordingly. With a polite client, if your price is too high for them, you can either find a way to reduce the scope of the project, or either of you can walk away with no hard feelings. It's business. This guy sounds like an asshole, but you didn't do yourself any favors by critiquing his code. Never tell a customer they are wring or incompetent. Just adopt your price to what you think the work will be, and take their contribution as well as their character into account. I hope you will get a real job as a developer soon and can stop dealing with such people.

gt;How do I gently put him down though? This is impossible. Don't try. Your customer obviously lacks the knowledge to complete the task, otherwise they wouldn't be hiring you. Therefore, if they think they have completed part of the task, it is impossible for them to estimate how large the part of the task is they have completed, as they have no model in their mind of how large the entire task is. There is no purpose in trying to talk to them about that, you can not win anything and can lose a lot. You have two choices in such a situation: a) Just leave out the task the customer thinks he solved from your list of tasks, and add the time it will take to the other tasks proportionally. Even go so far as to write that task down with a cost of zero and a note of "completed by customer" for that task. The customer will feel validated. Since the customer will also not be able to estimate the time needed for other tasks, it will be fine to estimate those a bit higher. b) Thank the customer for his valuable work, but say that you work with a standard style and way of doing things. Say you will incorporate his ideas into your solution, but you will need to rewrite it a bit. Offer him 10% cheaper cost, because he has already done part of the work. Then simply estimate the remainder 10% higher. You might think these ways of working are unethical. And to a degree, they might be. But your customer is not arguing in good faith either, and business is business - you need to look out for yourself. And in the end, you are offering the same price as you would have initially, but the customer feels good about his contribution, and you have a good way to not use their shitty work. In the end, when you present a working solution for the agreed-upon price, the customer will not care if his code made it into the final solution. He will probably not even think to check. If he does, tell him that you were forced to change his solution for technical reasons. He will not care - he only cares about price and a working solution. If you want to chat sometime, PM me. I have a lot of sympathy for your situation.

There are ways to make this work. Say you are a developer and estimate the project to take 20 hours. You want to be paid 25 USD per hour, so you estimate the cost of the project to be 500 USD. Now of course, the project can be done faster than that, or take longer than that. The best deal is when both parties (the developer and the customer) both benefit when the project takes less time, and both hurt when the project takes more time. This is because the customer can easily make the project take more time by increasing further requirements as the project progresses, or simply not accepting reasonable solutions to specified problems, expecting very sophisticated and expensive solutions. So a possible contract is: 25 USD per hour is fixed. If it takes less than 20 hours, we split the cost savings. For example, if the project only takes 16 hours, the developer gets paid for 18 hours (16 hours + 2 hours bonus), and the customer pays for 18 hours (20 hours - 2 hours bonus). So you both profit, because the developer gets paid 2 hours for no work, and the customer pays 2 hours less than he expected. If the project takes 24 hours, the developer gets paid 22 hours, so the customer pays more, but the developer gets paid less. This is a fairly complex contract, and for projects with a scope of around 100 USD its probably too complex. But this is just to give you and idea how professionals in business solve these problems. Edit: Another way is the agile/Scrum way. You say you will work for a certain amount of hours, and after those hours, you will present to the customer a working product. It might not do all the customer wants, but it is complete and can be used as it is. This is called a sprint. Then the customer can decide if he wants to buy another sprint. If he does, after it is done, you can present another working product that can do some things more than the last one. At any time, the customer can stop buying more sprints, and walk away with a working product. They have complete control over the process. However, they cannot expect an initial price for the final product - the vision and scope of the final project will change during all the sprints that are happening.

Not hashes, but public key cryptography. The problem is that each user needs to have a secret private key that the site admin cannot know. On apps like WhatsApp, this is saved om the phone. Where would you save it on a web app? The admin not being able to read messages absolutely requires a private key per user that the admin can't know.

I think there is something wrong with how you approach these questions. The examples you provide are very easy to do if you can write even basic programs. You must be approaching the problem wrong. Do you try to solve these verbally? Maybe it would help if you actually sat down with an IDE and wrote programs to solve these problems. For example "given an array with characters, return an array containing tuples of each character and the amount of times it is present": Actually write some examples of character arrays, like "AABC" and "ABCC". Then write their expected results, like "A:2, B:1, C:1" and "A:1, B:1, C:2" or similar. Then write a function that takes a character array as an input, and returns a list of tuples as an output. Then try to figure out how you would solve this problem if you had to do it manually. Then write the function to solve this problem, and test the function on the example inputs and outputs you came up with.

Your dictionary solution solved the problem. So the problem is not that you can't solve the problem, but you are unsure whether your solution is good or even optimal. That is a very different, and much better for you, situation. Providing the dictionary solution in detail on a whiteboard, and then discussion edge cases (does it work if no numbers are missing? if all numbers are missing? if its not 100 numbers, but only 1 number? 0 numbers?) will likely lead to you passing the test, as long as it's not a hardcore technical interview. Analyzing efficiency is a different problem. This is much more advanced than simply solving the problem. As a first step, you need to be able to reason about the efficiency of your solution. How many dictionary insertions and lookups are required? Then, after analyzing the performance of you solution, maybe start thinking of a more performant solution. What is the lowest amount of comparisons you have to do to solve the problem? Could you gain something by sorting the input data? It is very important to distinguish between being able to solve a problem, and being able to solve it optimally. Entry-level tests will want you to solve the problem and talk intelligently about your solution. That's it.

I think maybe the trouble is that you are reading material above your level. Take simple problems like these, and solve them with real code. You have shown that you can solve them once they make sense to you. Go solve 20 simple problems like that in code with all edge cases correct. Don't worry about big O notation of optimal solutions until you can routinely write code that solves simple problems like these.

In Switzerland, there are four spoken languages. Everybody learns the main language of the part of Switzerland they live in, and also one other Swiss language. In addition to that, everyone learns English. The main three languages spoken in Switzerland are German, French, and Italian. The fourth is not well known outside of Switzerland. So lets say your familiy moves to Zurich. They speak German there, so you would have to learn German anyway because everybody there talks German. Then you would learn French and English in school.

Yes, you are overreacting. Telling a friend you won't come help them with something because you told your GF you were tired earlier could easily ruin a friendship. He was open about the situation to you and there was no mean spirit involved. The only thing negative about this are your feelings of insecurity. Edit: You've been seeing each other 5 times a week without living together, and you get upset because he cancels once? Wow. Sometimes you just don't feed like hanging out, even with your SO. It's no big deal. If this is setting you off like this, there will be troubling times ahead. Just to be clear: He (and of course, you) should absolutely be able to cancel a normal meetup that occurs multiple times a week for no reason at all. You can't always be in the mood for seeing someone, it's just not possible.

I can empathize about not wanting to be a pushover. And if he did this kind of thing all the time, you should talk to him about it and stand up for yourself. On occasion, though, situations like this just happen. Even if your BF had cancelled you because he felt tired, introverted and in need of a night for himself. Then a friend calls and tries to talk him into going for some beers. He doesn't see the friend often, and the friend might be in need of company, or just offer a change of pace just as relaxing as spending the evening at home alone. How should your BF react? Call you to ask permission to see his friend? You are not his mother. Cancel the friend because he cancelled you, even though be wants to go? Who benefits from that? Also, what should he tell the friend? Lie to him? Or admit that he is cancelling the beer because he didn't feel like hanging out with you earlier, even though there is no direct connection? Let the guy live his life! Sure, stuff like this shouldn't be the norm, but in a trusting relationship you can do stuff liket his on occasion with no hard feelings. At least, that's how I feel.

My Grandfather, born and raised in Germany, smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this song gave me cancer anyway.

You must realize that there are cliques of students sharing infodumps of questions they create after taking tests. Once a question was on a test, it's out, whether it's on a public website or in a private document. By re-using questions on multiple tests, and going after publicly available questions , you are making it very beneficial to be in an in-group, and making test extremely unfair for students just learning the material on their own. How can you compete with other students who have access to old test questions when you don't? The only fair way is to publish all test questions a answers publicly after each test, and give this info to the students. Then write new questions every time. This takes time and effort, but well: This is your job. It's what you are paid to do. For my entire student life, this was a huge issue that otherwise intelligent professors just didn't understand. After EVERY test, students are going to sit down and write down all the questions they remember. After all, this is very valuable information. Then they distribute it somehow, in a way that is completely unregulated and benefits people who have the social capital required to get the info. This is not beneficial to education.

Students will share test questions. It's unreasonable to expect them not to. If a friend asks you about a test you did, of course you tell them what you remember. No honor code in the world is going to stop that. Going from there to making notes after the test in case someone asks, or to share with a group in exchange for notes about other tests, is a small step. By assuming only a few bad apples do this and you can stop it by punishing them, you are shifting the education to being more about who you know than what you know. I respect that writing tests is hard work. Ideally, there would be a huge, public pool of vetted questions, and creating a test would just be randomly selecting some of these. As long as there isn't such a pool, you need to share all old tests as part of the material for the course, and write new ones every time. There is no alternative to this if you want the education to be remotely fair.

I respect that you think behavior like this is not acceptable. However, if the risk of getting caught is near zero, and the benefit for you can be immense, people do things that you might find unacceptable. The questions is how you deal with imperfect people, and what the real-life consequences of your policy are. Did you understand my point about in-groups and the unfair advantages they get from policies like yours? gt; "I'm going to create a goddamn forum post in order to share as many stolen questions as I can so that future students can cheat." In my education, it was WhatsApp and Facebook groups or other closed social media. Sometimes student organizations had folder of physical knowledge dumps you could browse. Heck, at ETH the student organization officially sold copies of old tests and transcriptions of students memories of tests. That was a good system, as at least everyone had access to these collections. Of course, friends of the people involved often had more complete and earlier access to the documents, so it was still terribly unfair to people not in that particular in-group. Then you had student groups that lived together sharing info like this, or groups of students coming from a similar foreign country that formed cliques and shared this kind of info and varying schools and universities. Heck, if you are just a year behind a friend, sibling or lover of yours, they can be your single source for all test material! How the hell do you expect to stop childhood best friends or a couple from sharing info about the contents of your test? It's completely impossible! You HAVE to operate under the assumption that once a group of students took a test, the contents of the test will be shared with some students. The only fair way to handle the situation is to openly share it with ALL students. Anything else is morally wrong and incentivizes group membership rather than work ethic. gt; Ahahahahaha no that would be the worst possible way to do it because then you couldn't tailor anything to your own specific content or style of teaching. Of course you would have to create a pool of questions for your own individual class, you could not share these questions across classes on the same topic. gt; If some punk-ass kid stole that and published it online, I'd lose my number one question for distinguishing between smart kids who nevertheless can't think outside of a rote learnt box, and ingenious little buggers who can think on the fly and truly understand the course material rather than just regurgitating information. It's your job to come up with questions like this, again and again for every test. It's also your job to provide example questions like this, most easily taken from previous exams, so students can practice on questions of the difficulty level that will be on the test. Surprising students on the test with a question that is harder than any they had available to them during preparations is not about enhancing education. How could it be, being that it does not aid in study?

OK, now I can translate. The sentence you quoted in the title means: There will be various computer systems in a hospital. Each computer system has data saved in it. These computer systems will start to exchange data. However, the data stored on different systems might not be stored in the same way. For example, the same medication or the same condition might be stored under one code or name in system A, and another code or name in system B. A new type of nurse proficient in computers and software systems, called an informatics specialist nurse, will be needed. These people will understand the way data is stored on the different systems, so they can create mappings. A mapping is a part of a software system that translates (maps) the name of a thing on one system to its name on another system. These Informatics specialist nurses will also understand the systems and the data they contain so well, that they see the possibilities of creating processes that use data from multiple systems. For this to work, data needs to be transferred from one system to another system, mapped to the naming convention of the target system, then combined with the data on the target system to generate some kind of new information that can be used. This is unidirectional data flow. In some cases, it might even be a good idea for the resulting data to flow back to the original system, because it might be used there as well. That would be bidirectional data flow. Does that make sense to you? edit: The 26 is probably just a page number or something that got mixed in. It makes no sense.

I finished my education some time ago. I agree with your points to some degree. I still maintain that an effort should be made to make education systems fair. Otherwise, degrees mean nothing, and you might as well just learn the material online yourself. Sure, a good student with a good work-ethic will pass the class anyway, regardless of unfair access to previous questions by other students. It can make a big difference in your grades, though. And it's just so subjectively unfair that it massively degrades the experience of education.

I am trying to convince professors that they need to work harder to prevent cheating, by trying to explain the behavior of students. I am neither legitimizing the behavior, nor claiming to have done it. If fact, it was the same as you for me. I didn't cheat, wasn't in an in-group, and had a much harder time completing certain classes. While watching others easily coast through, because they had access to information I didn't . I still think that was very unfair, which is why I am trying to explain this point here. In fact, by writing new tests every time and sharing the results of the old tests, it will be harder for the students you describe to get a degree and work in your lab. The opposite: If it's harder to cheat and exams are more fair, the quality of people in your lab will go up!
In what way is it justifying bad behavior by pointing out it exists and proposing a simple way to eliminate its advantages?

gt;Which protocol and ports use the executors to talk to eachother? You can find that stuff here: [https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/configuration.html#networking](https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/configuration.html#networking) They communicate via an RPC port and a BlockManager port. They use raw sockets, i.e. a binary protocol over TCP. With the error you are getting, the issue is probably the BlockManager port. gt;How could I test the connectivity myself? You can test connectivity between executor nodes on the ports configured (spark.blockmanager.port) using NetCat. Set up a server on one executor, connect to it from another executor, using the port defined in that configuration.

One more thing: if an executor can't bind to the configured port, mostly because it is in use, it will retry one port higher, for maxretry times. So it might not be the exact port that is configured that is causing issues.
